Norma lives with her partner, is 30 years old and has 1 child who is 7 years old. Norma has a store next to her house where she sells groceries, sweets, vegetables, and meat. Furthermore, she works in agriculture growing vegetables and raising animals, which she sells in the city of Ayacucho with the help of her husband.

Norma needs a loan of 1000 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, noodles and fertilizer.

Norma dreams of growing her business, having her own restaurant, and of buying a computer for her son.

loans.use: Norma needs a loan of 1000 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, noodles and fertilizer.

loans.name: Hilda Maria's Group

texts.en:
Liz, Lucila, and Hilda María are all members of the Village Bank Lila. Liz is 27, single, and has one child, Lucila is 43 years old, married and has 5 children, and Hilda María is 48, single, and has 4 children. The three women have different businesses for which they use their loans from FINCA.

Liz has a business of selling cosmetics from house to house, and has been doing this for 2 years. Lucila sells sweets at the front doors of schools to children and has been doing this for 10 years.

Hilda María sells drinks such as beer and sodas out of her home, which she has been doing for 10 years.

Liz, Lucila, and Hilda María are asking for loans of 200 soles, 400 soles, and 200 soles, respectively, money which will be invested in the purchase of cosmetics, sweets, and soda and beer to add to their businesses.

Liz´s dream is to have enough money to support and raise her new baby, Lucila´s dream is to finish the house she is building, and Hilda María dreams that all her children will receive good educations.

loans.use: Liz, Lucila, and Hilda María are asking for loans of 200 soles, 400 soles, and 200 soles, respectively, money which will be invested in the purchase of cosmetics, sweets, and soda and beer to add to their businesses.

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris lives in the Colonia Primero de Mayo neighborhood. She is 53 years old and married. Her husband is retired and they have three grown children.

Doris operates a mobile disco rental business. She started her business with her own money and with the support of her husband and her son, who is living in the United States. If her loan is approved, Rosa will buy ceramic and make improvements to her home. Her plans are to improve the quality of her business’s musical equipment and to live a stable life.

Translated by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Doris habita en el barrio Colonia 1ro de Mayo, tiene 53 años de edad, es casada su esposo es ya jubilado y tiene 3 hijos que viven independientes.

El negocio de Doña Doris es alquiler de Disco Móvil, ella comenzó con dinero propio con la ayuda de su esposo y su hijo que está en Estados Unidos. Con este préstamo que le otorguen es para comprar cerámica y hacer mejoras a su vivienda. Sus planes son tener mejor calidad de sus equipos de trabajo, y un nivel de vida estable.

loans.use: Install ceramic in her house

loans.name: Lidia's Group

texts.en:
Julia, Haydee, and Lidia are all members of the Village Bank Muruina. Julia is 42 years old, married and has 2 children. Haydee is 27 years old, lives with her boyfriend, and has 1 child, and Lidia is 42 years old, married and has 3 children. The three women have different businesses for which they use their loans from FINCA. Julia sells typical Ayacuchan dishes in the market and has been doing this for about 1 year. Haydee sells cattle at the different fairs in the region, which she has been doing for about 1 year as well. Lidia sells typical Peruvian dishes that she cooks herself on Sundays at the market – she as also been doing this for 1 year. 
The women are asking for loans of 300 soles, 1000 soles, and 600 soles, respectively, to buy things to help grow their businesses. Julia will invest the money from the new loan in things for her kitchen such as utensils and plates and pots; Haydee will use the money to buy cattle; and Lidia will use the money from her new loan to buy more food with which she can prepare the traditional Ayacuchan dishes she sells on Sundays – she will buy things such as rice and chicken. 
The biggest dreams of these three women are that their children receive good educations and that they succeed in their studies.

loans.use: The women are asking for loans of 300 soles, 1000 soles, and 600 soles, respectively, to buy things to help grow their businesses. Julia will invest the money from the new loan in things for her kitchen such as utensils and plates and pots; Haydee will use the money to buy cattle; and Lidia will use the money from her new loan to buy more food with which she can prepare the traditional Ayacuchan dishes she sells on Sundays – she will buy things such as rice and chicken.

loans.name: Gerardo Armengol

texts.es:
Gerardo C. is 24 years old and works as a Managua city bus driver. He is married and has a 2-year-old daughter. His wife is a homemaker.

Five years ago Gerardo started working in his father’s business as a bus driver’s assistant. Because of his demonstrated responsibility on the job, he now drives that bus.

Gerardo’s dream is to finish building his house. He is requesting a loan to build a bedroom, which will make his family more comfortable. He hopes to provide a more decent home for his daughter and future children.

Translated by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva volunteer

Gerardo C. es un joven de 24 años de edad, que se dedica a conducir un bus de transporte colectivo en la ciudad de Managua. Es casado y tiene una niña de 2 años de edad, su esposa es ama de casa. Hace 5 años Gerardo empezó a laborar en el negocio de su padre como ayudante en un bus, pero gracias a la responsabilidad que ha demostrado en sus labores hoy en día es conductor de dicho bus. El sueño de Gerardo es poder terminar de construir su casa de habitación, por lo que solicita el préstamo para construir un cuarto de habitación para poder darle un poco mas de comodidad a su pequeña familia, espera poder darle a su hija una vivienda más digna y a los hijos que más adelante seguramente van a tener.

loans.use: Construction of a bedroom in his house

loans.name: Rosa Adela

texts.es:
Rosa lives in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood of Managua, where she operates a small business selling clothes. She also sells clothes door-to-door to her neighbors. She has been running this business for 5 years, during which time she has had to fight to keep her business going and to get ahead.

Rosa is married and has four children. Two of them are grown and she is raising the other two. Rosa needs a loan to build a wooden door and windows in her house in order to to complete her long-term home building project.

Translated by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva volunteer

D. Rosa habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de Managua, en donde tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de ropa, el que también realiza de forma ambulante entre sus vecinos. Tiene 5 años de tener este negocio tiempo en el cual ha tenido que luchar mucho para poder mantenerlo y lograr salir adelante.

D. Rosa está casada tiene 4 hijos, solamente dos de ellos se encuentran a su cargo, sus otros dos hijos son independientes a ella. Requiere del préstamo para construir una puerta y ventanas de madera en su casa de habitación para así continuar el proyecto que desde hace años atrás ha venido haciendo que es el de terminar de construir su casa por completo.

loans.use: Purchase two wooden doors and windows

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Douglas Jeovany

texts.es:
Douglas is 26 years old and lives in the municipality of Ticuantepe, in Managua, Nicaragua. He is married and has two children ages 4 and 7. His children are in school and his wife is a stay-at-home mother.

Douglas is a pineapple farmer and he has ten years of experience in the field. He began with hard work, and with this loan he would like to maintain and purchase a variety of agricultural supplies such as fertilizers and seeds.

In the future he would like to increase his production and sales, improve his living conditions and provide his children with an education.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Douglas tiene 26 años de edad, habita en el municipio de Ticuantepe, es casado y tienen dos hijos de 4 y 7 años de edad, los niños están estudiando, su esposa es ama de casa. El Sr. Douglas es agricultor de piña y lleva diez años de experiencia en los cultivos e inició con esfuerzos propios, y con este préstamo que le otorguen es para mantenimiento y compra de insumos agrícola. Sus planes futuros son tener una buena producción de sus productos y ventas, tener mejores condiciones de vida y brindar educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies used for cultivating pineapples

loans.name: Irma Maritza

texts.es:
Irma is 52 years old and lives in Laureles Norte in Managua, Nicaragua. She has two children, 18 and 20 years old, and she is single.

Irma’s business involves selling tortillas, beans, and nacatamales (a smaller version of regular tamales popular in Nicaragua, they include a corn meal base filled with meat or rice, stuffed in leaves and steamed). Irma began the business through hard work, and she now has six years of experience.

Irma plans to use her loan to purchase corn. In the future she would like to grow her business, improve her home, and educate her children.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Irma tiene 52 años de edad, habita en los Laureles Norte, y tiene dos niños de 18 y 20 años de edad, es soltera. El negocio de doña Irma es venta de tortillas, fríjoles y nacatamales, ella inició con esfuerzos propios tiene seis años de experiencia. Con el préstamo que le otorguen es para invertirlo en capital en la compra de maíz.A futuro es agrandar el negocio, mejorar su vivienda y educar a sus hijos.

loans.use: To purchase corn for making tortillas

loans.name: Mann

texts.en: Mrs. Mann P., 31, grows crops behind her house and earns about a $1 per day, Her husband, Soun Khy, is 39 years-old and sells fish in the market, earning about $4 per day. They have three children, all of whom are young and in school. The family lives in Betmeas Village of the Province of Siem Reap. P. is requesting a loan of $500 to buy farmland to expand her farming business. This will help her grow and sell more crops, and thereby increase her income.

loans.use: To buy farmland to expand farming business

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en: Mrs. Chantha M. and her husband, Mr. Chansovath Choy, are teachers in Tumnop Thmey village in Kampong Chhnang Province. They have two young children. Because teachers' salaries are very small (25/month),  Mrs. Chantha M. also sells firewood. She is requesting a loan to buy buffaloes for breeding. This will improve her income and help raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy buffaloes for breeding.

loans.name: Phlong

texts.en: Mrs. Phlong S., is a 51-year-old widow. She sells porridge and raises pigs from her house, earning $2 per day. Mrs. S. has two children, one of whom is married and one of whom lives with the family in their house. Her son that lives with her, Mr. Rin Rith, is 32 years-old and earns $3.80 per day from his billiards business. She requests a loan of $600 so she can purchase a stock of groceries and decorate the storefront part of her home. A grocery business will increase her earning potential.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of groceries and to decorate the storefront part of her home

loans.name: Chek

texts.en: Chek S. is 57 years old and sells fruit in the Kampong Cham province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$5 every day. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions have lead to a poor growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$800 to make two investments. She would like to invest US$500 in her sister’s rice business, and also put US$300 into her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell. She sees these investments as opportunities that will be able to increase her daily income.

loans.use: Increasing fruit stock; Investing in sister's rice business.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S. is 25 years old, has one child and resides with her husband in Phnom Penh. She works selling vegetables and groceries. She is able to make $4 of profit each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. To meet growing customer demand, Sem is requesting for a loan to add to inventory. The loan will help to meet her customer demand. ( Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Sem S. was unavailable)

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to meet her customer demand.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Nuon C., 35, sells small freshwater shells in the local market of her Kampong Cham province. She is married with two children, who are still living at home.  Her husband works in construction. She typically makes about US$6 each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$300 to purchase more shells to sell in the market.

loans.use: Purchase more shells

loans.name: Chuichojojche Group

texts.es:
This group of women come from Chuichijojche, a community located in the high mountains of the Nahuala municipality, which is covered by plantations of corn, bean, wheat and potato. Nahuala is know for its winters, where heavy rain and thick clouds fall over the municipality.

The Chuichijojche group has been working together for five years. This creates a very special dynamic within the group, creates an environment of trust, and it also sees to it that the years don't pass in vain. You notice this trust in the cheerfulness of the group at the repayment meetings. This positive feeling which is abundant in this group is based in the most essential foundation - the responsibility. This group has been able to stay together for such a long time because they are responsible women who pay on time.

All of the group members sell traditional Guatemalan dresses. They sell fabrics, long skirts, traditional hand-woven and embroidered blouses and hipbelts. The women sell their goods at the main markets of the plain, such as Solola, Xela and Totonicapán. They already have regular buyers. A few of them work as street traders or tend to clients in their homes. The women not only have assigned buyers, but also have craftspeople who sew for them on demand. Many of them also already have a group of craftswomen they buy from directly.

The group members believe that the credit has supported them because they can purchase more typical clothing wholesale and thereby increase their profit. They all think that without the loan they wouldn't be able to get ahead. Because of this they are excited about breaking the taboo of coming together for a group loan.

The biggest challenge facing this group of women is coping with both their businesses and also their domestic chores. Many say that looking after their children and husbands and also keeping up with the housework is an additional job.

The Chuichijojche group is a cheerful and united group. They have already made a lot of progress over the last five years and it's because of this that we should support them so that they can continue fighting.

Translated from [Spanish] by [Lisa Ritchie], Kiva Volunteer.

P>El reto más grande para este grupo de mujeres es el de lidiar con sus negocios y los quehaceres de la casa. Muchas argumentan que atender a los niños y al esposo y tener la casa ordenada es un trabajo aparte.

El grupo Chuichijojche es un grupo alegre y unido, ellas ya han venido saliendo adelante desde hace cinco años es por eso que nosotros las deberíamos de apoyar para que así puedan seguir luchando.

Este gran grupo de mujeres provienen de Chuichijojche, una comunidad ubicada en las altas montañas del municipio de Nahuala, donde las lomas están cubiertas por plantaciones de maíz, fríjol, trigo y papa. Nahuala es conocida por sus inviernos, donde fuertes lluvias y densas neblinas recaen sobre dicho municipio.

El grupo Chuichijojche ha venido trabajando junto desde hace cinco años. Esto crea una dinámica muy especial dentro del grupo, crea un ambiente de confianza, esto se debe a que los años no pasan en vano. Esta confianza se hace notar cuando las integrantes del grupo se ríen constantemente durante las reuniones de repago. Este sentimiento positivo que abunda en este grupo yace en la base más ensencial, la responsabilidad. Este grupo a podido permanecer tanto tiempo juntas porque son mujeres responsables que pagan puntualmente.

Todas las integrantes de este grupo son vendedoras de trajes típicos de Guatemala. Ellas venden cortes, faldas largas, huipiles, blusas tejidas a mano y bordadas, rebosos y fajas. Las señoras salen a los mercados principales del altiplano, tales como Solola, Xela, Totonicapán a vender. Ellas ya tienen sus compradores listos, muy pocas son las que venden de manera ambulante o que esperan a los compradores dentro de sus casas. Las señoras no solo tienen su compradores asignados, pero también tienen las artesanas que les tejen a su disposición. Muchas, ya tienen un grupo de artesanas que les compran directamente.

Las integrantes del grupo creen que el crédito las ha ayudado porque ellas pueden comprar más ropa típica al por mayor y así incrementar las ganancias. Todas piensan que sin el préstamo ellas no podrían salir adelante. Es por eso que ellas se animaron a romper el taboo de unirse a un grupo de créditos.

El reto más grande para este grupo de mujeres es el de lidiar con sus negocios y los quehaceres de la casa. Muchas argumentan que atender a los niños y al esposo y tener la casa ordenada es un trabajo aparte.

El grupo Chuichijojche es un grupo alegre y unido, ellas ya han venido saliendo adelante desde hace cinco años es por eso que nosotros las deberíamos de apoyar para que así puedan seguir luchando.

loans.use: To buy traditional clothing.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi A., 47 years old, joined TYM since 2003.  Her family main sources of incomes are farming, raising cattles and weaving mattress.  With the first loA. of 500,000 dong from TYM, she bought materials to weave and was able to achieve some early success.  Due to her good planning, she had been able to repay all the payments and has been willing to borrow larger amount in following cycle to buy foodstuff for her pigs.  She has 3 children but one is already working (making 1.5 million VND per month) so her family's income is quite stable.  Her family would like to borrow 6 million VND to buy more material for weaving mattress.  Her family income is about 3 million VND per month.

 Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Ân 47 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2003, nghề nghiệp chính của gia đình chị là làm ruộng, chăn nuôi và dệt chiếu, được vay vốn của Quỹ là cơ hội để gia đình chị phát triển kinh tế, với 500.000đ vốn vay bA. đầu được anh chị sử dụng vào mua vật liệu để dệt chiếu, sử dụng vốn hiệu quả nên việc trả tuần là phù hợp với gia đình chị, khi đã quen với việc trả tuần gia đình chị đã mạnh giạn vay ở mức vốn cao hơn và đầu tư thêm vào chăn nuôi lợn, vừa dệt chiếu vừa chăn nuôi nên thu nhập gia đình chị rất ổn định, chi có 3 con, 2 con chị đang đi học, 1 con đã đi làm thu nhập bình quân  1.500.000đ/ tháng. Vợ chồng chị bàn bạc vòng vốn này xin vay 6.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua vật liệu dệt chiếu.
Thu nhập bình quân 3.000.000đ/tháng

loans.use: Weaving mattress

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem H., 72, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her daughters in the Kampong Cham province.  She typically makes about US$2 each day.  Her daughter, Soy Un, makes about US$2 each day as a garment factory worker. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Hem H. included. She has 8 other children, but they are married and no longer live at home. Hem H. would like a loan of US$300 to purchase a sewing machine allowing her to begin a business in her home. A sewing machine would increase profits and it would also allow for her daughter to stop working in the factory.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi C.. 54 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2004. Before, she used the borrowed money in buying fishing equipments since fishing is her family’s main activity. She has 5 children. 3 of whom are living separately, one of whom is working abroad and the last child is living with her to help her. Her husband is a retired worker with a pension of 80 USD/month. Not only because of old age but also because her children are not all available to help her, she decides to stop fishing and start breeding pigs. This time, she wants to borrow 375 USD to invest in breeding pigs. Her average income is 250 USD/ month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Chuông 54 tuổi, năm 2004 chị tham gia Quỹ, những năm về trước gia đình chị làm nghề biển các nên các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ gia đình chị đều đầu tư vào săm đồ nghề đi biển, nghề đó cũng là thu nhập chính của gia đình chị, chị có 5 người con, 3 con đã lập gia đình và ra ở riêng, 2 con đang sống cùng vợ chồng anh chị trong đó có 1 người đi xuất khẩu lao động nước ngoài 1 người ở nhà phụ giúp công việc bố mẹ, chồng chị là cán bộ về hưu lương 1.000.000đ/ tháng, số lao động trong gia đình đã giảm và chị cũng đã nhiều tuổi nên chị đã quyết định bỏ nghề đi biển và chuyển hướng sang chăn nuôi. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 6.000.000đ đầu tư vào nuôi lợn nái. Thu nhâp bình quân 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: breeding pigs

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi S. joined the TYM Fund since 2004. At first, she used the borrowed money in breeding pigs. After 4 years of membership, she is familiar with the repaying method. She decides to invest in selling birds, for pets and for food. This activity helps improving her family economy. She has 4 children, one of whom is building his own family, one of whom is still going to school, the other two are working and contributing their income. Her husband is a building worker, earning 100 USD/month. This time, she wants to borrow 575 USD to continue her bird-selling activity. Her average income is 250 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Năm 2004 chị Lê Thi Sáu tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, qua 4 năm tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị đã quen dần với việc trả tuần, với những mức vốn ban đầu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị đã chuyển hướng kinh doanh buôn bán chim, buôn bán các loại chim cảnh và chim thịt, với hoạt đọng buôn bán này kinh tế gia đình chị ngày một phát triển, chị có 4 người con, 1 con đã xây dựng gia đình, 1 con đang đi học, 2 con đã đi làm và có thu nhập giúp gia đình, chồng chị làm nghề thợ xây thu nhập bình quân 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào buôn bán chim. Thu nhập bình quân 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: bird-selling

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Phaung

texts.en: Phaung S. I., 34, is married with four young children living at home in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US$1 each day and her husband raises pigs. Her husband, Phin Pai, typically makes about US$2 each day as a pig farmer. Phaung S. I. would like a loan of US$600 to purchase more pigs to breed and to purchase feed for the pigs. This loan would allow for their family to increase their profits from raising the pigs.

loans.use: Purchase a pig

loans.name: Chiv

texts.en: Chiv N., 29, is a professional tailor, making US$3 each day in the Kampong Cham province. She is married and has one child living at home. Her husband, Yem Yea, makes approximately US$2.50 every day, making incense. Chiv N. would like a loan of US$500 to purchase three more sewing machines for her business. She will be able to increase her profits byhiring employees to run these machines.

loans.use: Purchase three sewing machines

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 51 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2003. She has one daughter who is attending a university. She used the borrowed money in breeding pigs and ducks. After 5 years of membership, her breeding projects went very effectively. She decided to borrow money to buy rice-husking machine to assist local people. Her family economy improves. She is able to pay the tuition fee for her daughter’s school and furnish her house. This time, she wants to borrow 575 USD to continue investing in pigs and ducks. Her average income is 250 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị H. 51 Tuổi, tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương năm 2003, vợ chồng anh chi có 1 con gái hiện đang đi học đại học, khi tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lơn, vịt đẻ, sau 5năm tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị vay vốn đầu tư vào các dự án đều đem lại hiệu quả kinh tế cao, gia đình chị đã đầu tư vốn mua máy sát gạo phục vụ nhu cầu của người dân quanh địa phương, kinh tế gia đình chị ngày một phát triển gia đình chị đã mua sắm được nhiều tiên nghi trong gia đình và đầu tư cho con đi học đại học. Vòng vốn này gia đình xin vay 9.000.000đ. tiếp tục đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi lợn và vịt đẻ. Thu nhập bình quân. 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: invest in breeding pigs and ducks

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Q., 57 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) in 2003.  She has 5 children, all got married.  She now lives with one of them.  Mrs. Q. borrowed money from TYM Fund to breed animals and buy materials to make mats.  Since she has many experiences in making mats, her business is very good.  She has so many customers and all of her mats are sold out very quickly.  Besides making mats, Mrs. Q. also breeds pigs.  She currently ha 5 pigs that are ready to be sold.  This time she wants to borrow 375 USD to breed pigs and to buy materials to make mats.
On average, Mrs. Q. approximately 219USD per month.

 Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Quyền 57 tuổi, năm 2003 chị tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, chị có 5 người con đã xây dựng gia đình, hiện nay chị sống cùng 1 người con, tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và mua vật liệu dệt chiếu, với kinh nghiệm gia đình có nhiều năm làm nghề dệt chiếu nên công việc làm ăn của gia  chị  rất thuận lợi, khách đến mua chiếu của gia đình chị rất đông, sản phẩm chiếu nhà chị làm không kịp bán, ngoài việc thu nhậ từ nghề dệt chiếu gia đình chị còn thu nhập từ chăn nuôi lợn, hiện nay gia đình chị đang có 5 con lợn thịt đang chờ xuất. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 6.000.000 đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và mua vật liệu dệt chiếu.
Thu nhập bình quân 3.500.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Tzanjay Group

texts.es:
The woman from the Tzanjay community come from a delightful village located at the banks of Lake Atitián in the bay of San Juan. It is a very progressive village. In this you can see beautiful murals, painted by local artists, a small but modern library, clean streets and a central market which has very interesting architecture. Furthermore, several foreigners have gone to San Juan to invest in different environmental projects which will benefit the community; projects such as low-energy cookers and recycling, among others.

The Banco Comunal Tzanjay has been working together for four years. All this time the same group of women have been applying for loans from The Friendship Bridge. This institution appealed to them because it doesn't ask for exclusionary prerequisites. Instead, a group of twenty women, photocopy the applicants' identity documents offers them a relatively inexpensive loan plus advice.

This group of woman manage their credit very well. So that they could apply for this loan as soon as possible, they decided to accelerate the repayment of their previous loan. The main reason for this loan is the upcoming village fair. They would like to have capital to invest in their businesses and thus meet the demand that will arise at this event.

Half of the group are craftswomen. They sew beautiful linen textiles, which are used for making "huipiles" - traditional backstrap blouses from the Guatemalan plain. They are also good businesspeople. The other half of the group have grocery stores, selling ham, noodles, sugar, rice etc.

The women say it is thanks to God that their businesses are running well. The previous loan enabled them to increase their working capital to a point where they always have enough to meet the demand from their clientele. For example, one woman says that her clientele is still stable, despite the heavy rain which drenched the plain of Guatemala, The craftswomen who produce textiles and dyes with natural colours say there is a lot of foreign demand for these products, and that it's because of this that their sales are stable throughout the year. Another said that she has a grocery store, and has been investing the profits in the production of "hacky sacks" - small textile balls filled with rice - which are also sold abroad.

The women like working in this group because they like the advice, which the credit agency provides them. They also have fun while chatting with their clients. However, what's most important for them is that all the clients are courteous.

The dream of these women is that their dear bay of San Juan continues developing to the point that it becomes an example to the rest of the neighboring communities around the lake. They also dream that their businesses grow and that their family situations improve. Such noble goals should be supported by noble investments. Think about it!

Translated from [Spanish] by [Lisa Ritchie], Kiva Volunteer.

Las mujeres de la comunidad Tzanjay provienen de un hermoso pueblo ubicado a las orillas del lago Atitlán, San Juan la laguna. San Juan, es un pueblo muy progresista. En este se puede ver bellos murales hechos por artistas locales, una pequeña pero moderna biblioteca, calles limpias y un mercado central que tiene una infraestructura muy interesante. Además, en San Juan varios extranjeros han ido a invertir en distintos proyectos medio ambientales que benefician a la comunidad, tales como cocinas ahorradoras, reciclaje entre otros.

El banco comunal tzanjay ha venido trabajando juntos desde hace cuatro años. Todo este tiempo este mismo grupo de señoras han venido pidiendo préstamos a The Friendship Bridge. Ellas acudieron a dicha institución porque esta no le pedía requisitos salvo un grupo de veinte mujeres, fotocopia de su documento de identidad nacional y fotocopia de cédula y ha cambio les ofrecía un préstamo relativamente barato más capacitación.

Este grupo de señoras se nota que dominan muy bien el crédito ya que ellas decidieron adelantar el pago de la última cuota del préstamo anterior para poder solicitar este crédito lo antes posible. La razón principal, es la feria del pueblo. Ellas quieren tener capital para invertir en sus negocios y así aprovechar la demanda que trae dicho evento.

La mitad del grupo son artesanas. Ellas tejen bellos lienzos de tela que son utilizados para hacer los huipiles, blusas tradicionales del altiplano de Guatemala. También, podemos encontrar comerciantes. La otra mitad del grupo son tienen tiendas de consumo diario. En ellas, las clientas venden jabones, fideos, azucar, arroz, etc.

Las señoras argumentan que gracias a Dios les va bien en el negocio. El préstamo las ha ayudado a incrementar su capital de trabajo al punto donde siempre tienen lo necesario para satisfacer la demanda de su clientela. Por ejemplo, una señora dice que a pesar de las duras lluvias que han venido asotando el altiplano de Guatemala, la clientela es estable. Las artesanas que trabajan elaborando tejidos y tiñendolos con tintes naturales dicen que esos productos tienen mucha demanda en el exterior, es por eso que su venta es estable a lo largo del año. Otra clienta, contó que ella tiene una tienda de consumo, pero con las ganancias ella ha estado invirtiendo en la elaboración de hacky sacks, pequeñas pelotas tejidas rellenas de arroz que también se venden al extranjero.

A las señoras les gusta trabajar en grupo porque les gusta las capacitaciones que les da las agentes de crédito, además de divertirse mucho durante las dinámicas de rompe hielo. Sin embargo, lo más importante es que todas las clientas son cumplidas.

El sueño de estas señoras es que su querido San Juan la laguna siga desarrollando al punto que sea un municipio ejemplo para el resto de comunidades alrededor del lago. Ellas también sueñan con que su negocio crezca y sus familias estén mejor. Metas tan nobles deberían de ser apoyadas con inversiones nobles, piénsalo.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for fabric and to buy products for a grocery store.

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
Try M., age 28, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh. To supplement the household income, she works as a seamstress transporting small piece of clothes from the factory and make them in order and sell for a profit.  On average, she makes $1 per day. Her husband Mr. Van Nean, 27, is a construction foreman since 2001. He works from place to place and earn $6 each day. One of their children is a student, and the rest are too young to attend the school.
He is requesting a loan to help purchase more construction tools. This will make his work easier. The leftover would be used to buy wood to repair the leaking roof.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools for her husband to work.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng L., 55, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her nieces in the Kampong Cham province. She typically makes US$2 each day and would like to increase her profits. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Heng L. included. She is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase fertilizer for the farm, increasing her current profits and improving her prospects for the future.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Lucianitas Group

texts.es:
The Lucianitas group come come from the Paquip village, which is situated in the municipality of Santa Clara. The only way to reach this location is by travelling to the Palestina canton by a microbus, before walking for 45 minutes. However, when I went there for the interview, I had to walk another 45 minutes in the rain, as the bus driver didn't reach Palestina, and so I had to walk to the center of Santa Clara. This was an incredible experience, as I was walking through the green mountains surrounded by a deep calm.

All of the Lucianitas manufacture belts from beads. These belts are used by indigenous women to decorate their materials or long skirts. The Lucianitas sell the belts to traders who come to Paquip to collect the goods. Together with their respective families, this group of women work very hard to earn their daily bread. Each belt sells at US$6 and it takes one person a whole day to produce one belt.

These women usually work alone and are helped by their daughters after they arrive home from school and do their homework. In Paquip, all girls start producing these belts from the age of 9.

The Lucianitas have been working together for 6 years. During this time, the clients have achieved a unique harmony. This harmony is due to the courtesy of the women. Furthermore, all of these years they have felt very comfortable with the credit agent Gloria Cholotio and also with The Friendship Bridge. They say that they like the Friendship Bridge because an alternative local loan would be very expensive, with monthly fees of up to 10%.

The dream of the Lucianitas is to see their childR. complete school and maybe even university. They all support their childrens' education. They see that their childR. have the opportunity to get an education that they never had. It's because of this that they blindly support the development of their families and we really ought to do the same.

Translated from [Spanish] by [Lisa Ritchie], Kiva Volunteer.

Las Lucianitas provienen D. la aldea Paquip ubicada en el municipio D. Santa Clara. La única manera D. llegar a este lugar es llegar al cantón D. Palestina en un microbús y luego caminar por 15 minutos. Sin embargo cuando yo fui a la entrevista tuve que caminar 45 minutos bajo la lluvia, ya que el conductor D. los microbuses no llegaron a Palestina y tuve que caminar hasta el centro D. Santa Clara. Esta fue una experiencia realmente increíble ya que estaba caminando al medio D. las montañas verdes rodeado por una paz única.

Todas las Lucianitas elaboran cinturones a base D. mostacilla. Estos cinturones son utilizados por las mujeres indígenas para adornar sus cortes o faldas largas. Ellas venden sus cinturones a los intermediarios que vienen a Paquip a recoger la mercadería. Junto con sus respectivas familias este grupo D. mujeres trabajan muy duro para ganarse el pan D. cada día. Para elaborar un cinturón una persona se demora un día entero y venden cada uno a US$6. Lamentablemente, el intermediario se lleva gran parte D. la ganancia.

Usualmente estas mujeres trabajan solas y cuando sus hijas llegan del colegio las ayudan a elaborar las cintas después D. hacer sus tareas. En Paquip todas las niñas empiezan a elaborar estos cinturones desD. que tienen 9 años D. edad.

Las Lucianitas han venido trabajando juntos por 6 años. Durante este tiempo las clientas han logrado una armonía única. Esta armonía se debe a que todas las señoras son cumplidas. Además, todos estos años ellas se han sentido muy cómodas con la agente D. crédito Gloria Cholotio y con la institución. Ellas dicen que les gusta Friendship Bridge porque un prestamista local les cobra muy caro, esto pueD. llegar hasta un 10% al mes.

El sueño D. las Lucianitas es D. ver a sus hijos graduarse del colegio y porque no la universidad. Todas ellas apoyan la educación D. sus hijos. Ellas sienten que sus hijos tienen la oportunidad D. educarse que ellas no tuvieron o no le ofrecieron. Es por eso que ellas ciegamente apoyan el desarrollo D. sus familias y ¡nosotros deberíamos D. hacer lo mismo!

loans.use: To buy beads and thread to produce belts.

loans.name: Chhea

texts.en: Chhea Y., 54, is a widowed farmer who lives with her only daughter. Living in the Kampong Cham province, she typically makes US$1 every day and is aided by her daughter who works in a garment factory. The Kampong Cham area has not seen favorable weather conditions for farming this past year. Along with increased inflation, it has been a difficult year economically in much of Cambodia. As a farmer, Chhea Y. is taking a lot of the brunt of the economic downturn. That is why she has approached CREDIT with a request for a loan. Chhea Y. is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase of fertilizer, a purchase that she sees as a good opportunity to increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea Y., 52, is married and lives with four of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day and are supported by three children working in the garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chea Y. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$200 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Hy

texts.en:
Mr. Hy S. and Mrs. Chhong Dyong are married and live in Chymeas Village, Kampong Thom Province. They are farmers and they earn  around $5.3 per day.
They have six children, one of whom is married. Two of their children are working for garment factories and another is a fisherman. They are requesting a loan of $1,100 to use for farming on their large farmland and to purchase rice seeds. This will expand their farming business and improving family’s income. They hope to make their living conditions better.

loans.use: For farming expenses and to purchase rice seed

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm V., 46, is married and lives with seven of her children in the Kampong Cham province. Working a farm together with her husband, Morm V. typically makes US$1.50 each day. Her family is also supported by two of the children who work in the garment factory and one child who is in construction. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Morm V. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase fertilizer for their farm, a purchase that she believes can bring an increase to her daily income.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him S., 33, is married and lives with her three young children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US$5 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Him S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$250 to expand her farmland. In order to increase her profits and possibly raise her standard of living, she would like to purchase more land to produce rice with the loan given to her through CREDIT.

loans.use: Purchase farmland

loans.name: Yeun

texts.en: Mrs. Yeun M. is a villager in Trapaing Chum Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 43 years old and a widow with four children. One child works in a garment factory and another is a construction worker. The remaining two attend school. Mrs. Yeun M. is a subsistence farmer and traditional healer. Even though three family members work, they live in poverty conditions in a very old house. Mrs. Yeun M. is requesting a loan so she can build a new house for her family. She previously got a loan to buy rice stock, and that loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa A., 42, is married and lives with her seven children in the Kampong Cham province. She works as a farmer, making approximately US$1.50 each day, and her husband works in construction and makes US$2 income each day  Two children also work in garment factories. Hoa A. is asking for a loan of US$380 to purchase fertilizer and hire a tractor to plow the land. She believes that these purchases will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer. Hire tractor to plow land.

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en: Mrs. Sophat U. is a grocer in Trapaing Krobao Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 54 and a widow with two children. one child breeds pigs and the other is a farmer. The child who breeds pigs has improved business and is ready to expand.  Mrs. Sophat U. is requesting a loan to  to buy three pigs for her child's business. Previously, Mrs. Sophat U. obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to purchase more grocery goods to start her grocery business. This loan was successfully repaid.

loans.use: To buy three pigs for her child's business.

loans.name: Kheang

texts.en: Kheang A. is married and lives with two of her children. She works as a farmer in the Kampong Cham province, typically making US$2 each day, and she is supported by her husband who works and sells land. Her husband needs a backhoe to first dig up the land before he can sell it, so the family would like a loan of $1200 to rent a backhoe. In the future, the family hopes to purchase a backhoe to work the land, but for now a loan to rent will bring an increase of income to the family.

loans.use: Rent a backhoe

loans.name: Muth

texts.en: Mr. Muth C. is a villager in Roka Tong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He has a rice plantation. Mr. Muth C.’s rice field is now infertile, so Mr. Muth C. is requesting a loan to buy more fertilizers to support his field. His wife, Mrs. Sophe Pach, is also a farmer. Mr. Muth C. is 46 and the father of four children, two of whom are subsistence farmers while one other is attending school. The remaining one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to support his field.

loans.name: Vek

texts.en: Vek L., 58, is married and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer, making US$2 every day, and her husband grows vegetables, making approximately US$3 each day. They are also supported by two of the children who are employed. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and rising inflation has affected all Cambodians. These factors have made a difficult economic year for much of the country, Vek L. included. In light of the country’s economic difficulties, Vek L. is seeking to increase her income and expand her land. She is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more land to grow rice. With this new land she believes she will see an increase in her income and her standard of living will be raised.

loans.use: Purchase farmland

loans.name: Sous

texts.en: Sous S., 45, is a widow with four children and resides in Phnom Penh. Since 2006 she works as a construction worker and earn $2.50. Two of her children are employed in the factory and the rest are students. Now Sous is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a sewing machine for her children to sew at home after regular working hours in a factory. This will provide an extra income to support the family. As of right now, there is flooding around her house so the taioring business will start in the next couple months when the dry season is coming. (Mrs. Sous S. is sitting at the front door of her house)

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for her children to tailor at home when they are free from the factory.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is a wife of M. A. and the mother of six children, three sons and three daughters.

All of her children are well educated. Her first son, Bashir Hussain, has a Masters degree. The next son, Sohail Hussain is in 12th standard grade. Shahid Hussain, a younger son, is 18 years old and received education until the 8th standard grade and then started a livestock business (buffalo).

Her two older daughters are married and settled in their own houses. Her youngest daughter is 21 years old and she received education until the 10th standard grade.

Naseem and her husband, A., want to give their children a good education. Her husband is a farmer. He sells wheat and rice on contract and earns a good income. Naseem is a housewife who does houseworks and sews clothes for herself.

Naseem successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution. With the first loan, she bought a buffalo. Now she is applying to buy another buffalo. Her daily income is $42 per day.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo

loans.name: Bilquis

texts.en:
Bilquis baji, a wife of A. M., lives in a three-room brick house in Kasur, Pakistan. She is a mother of four children, two sons and two daughters. Her husband is a driver and drives his own vehicle, which is called a "Coaster."

Bilquis baji sells milk, so she needs a buffalo to expand her milk business and improve her financial condition. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo

loans.name: Waziran

texts.en:
Waziran baji, wife of A. H., lives in Kasur, Pakistan, a city that is famous for its sweatmeat. Waziran baji has a good reputation in her neighborhood. Everybody gives her respect. Waziran baji has a two-room brick house and one big hallway. She does housework and she sells milk and earns a good profit. Her daily income is $10 to $15.

She is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo in order to expand her milk business.

NOTE: "Baji" (elder sister) is an Urdu term of respect for women.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her milk business

loans.name: Chansum Sut Group

texts.en: The group leader in this group of 4 is Mrs. Chansum S.. Mrs. Chansum S. is 32 and the mother of four children, all of whom are attending school. Mrs. Chansum S. has a small  rice plantation business in Trapaing Preal Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She usually hires a laborer with cows to plow her rice field, but she cannot afford this at the present time. She is requesting a loan to pay for a laborer. Her husband, Mr. Thea Chan, is a fisherman.

loans.use: To pay for a laborer to plow her rice field.

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Chhoun S., 59, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. Selling Khmer noodles, she makes $6 each day, and her husband works construction making $3 each day. Chhoun S. is asking for a loan of $1000 to raise ducks for their eggs. She sees this purchase a good investment to expand her business and she is confident it will increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase ducks

loans.name: Hamidan

texts.en:
Hamidan baji, wife of M. Ramzan, lives in Kasur, Pakistan, a city that is famous for its sweatmeat. Hamidan baji is a housewife. She also embroiders decorative dresses, scarves, and shirts; a God-given skill. She tries to work on her skill and improve the quality of her products. She has been doing this work for the last 5 years. Now she considers it to be her profession. She needs a loan to fulfill the orders of her customers.

NOTE: "Baji" (elder sister) is an Urdu term of respect for women.

loans.use: To expand her embroidery business

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en:
Rubina baji, wife of S. A., lives in Kasur, Pakistan, a city that is famous for its sweatmeat. Rubina baji is a housewife and a seamstress. She sews clothing on order. She has been in this profession for the last 5 years. She needs a loan to fulfill the orders from her customers. Her daily income is $10 to $12. She wants to expand her business and start a stitching center where she trains girls so that they can start their own sewing businesses.

NOTE: "Baji" (elder sister) is an Urdu term of respect for women.

loans.use: To expand her sewing business and start a training center

loans.name: Yarng

texts.en: Yarng N., 29, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband (pictured above) and three young children. She works as a farmer, making $1 a day, and is supported by her husband who collects palm juice, making $2 a day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also forced food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these times of economic difficulties, Yarng N. is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase pig food and to help her raise a pig. She is an ambitious entrepreneur who one day hopes to set up a grocery store in front of her home. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that her business venture will be successful.

loans.use: Purchase pig food

loans.name: Sardaran

texts.en:
Sardaran baji, wife of M.S., lives in a two-room brick house in Kasur, Pakistan. Sardaran baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is a mother of four children. Sardaran baji and her husband have a good reputation in their neighborhood. Her husband drives an auto-rickshaw taxi (a three-wheeled vehicle often known as a 'tuk-tuk'). He has been in this profession for the last 10 years. Now, she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband to drive.

NOTE: 'Baji' (elder sister) is an Urdu term of respect for women.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en:
Zubaida, the wife of S. A. lives Kasur, Pakistan. She is a housewife and helps her husband with his business, in which he manufactures washing powder and soaps. Her husband has been in this profession for the last 15 years and now, he has become an expert in it. He is well recognized in his neighborhood, as well as in other areas. His monthly income is $250 to $300.

Zubaida successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute of Pakistan. Now, she is applying for a loan for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To expand her husband's soap business

loans.name: Sugran

texts.en:
Sugran baji is a wife of B. A.. She lives in Kasur, Pakistan in a three-room brick house. She is a mother of two children, one daughter and one son. Sugran baji is a milk seller that’s why she requires a buffalo. She wants to expand her milk business and improve the financial condition. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah a microfinance institute of Pakistan.

NOTE: "Baji" (elder sister) is an Urdu term of respect used for women.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Guzal

texts.ru:
Guzal is 27 years old. She is single and lives with her parents. She is the head of a sewing shop. She needs a loan to be able to repair her apartment. Her parents have given her an apartment and she would like to repair it. However, she does not want to take money out of the business because during the past winter there were issues with electricity and it was necessary to close the shop. Guzal let the workers go home because it was impossible to work in the cold and without light. In addition to that most of the sewing machines require electricity. She has already borrowed money before for the business and was able to fully repay the loan. This time she has come to us for a consumer loan.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Гузаль 27 лет она не замужем, живет с родителями. Она руководит швейным цехом . Ей необходим кредит для ремонта своей квартиры. Ее родители подарили квартиру, и она решила сделать ремонт. Но с бизнеса ей не хотелось брать , потому что этой зимой были проблемы со светом и цех вынуждены были остановить. Гузаль отпустила работников, так как невозможно было работать в холодных условиях зимы и при отсутствии света, большинство швейных машинок работали на электричестве. Она раньше кредитовалась и получала кредит для бизнеса, закончив кредитование без проблем, она опят обратилась к нам, теперь она получила кредит для личного пользования.

loans.use: Repair of Apartment

loans.name: Ke

texts.en: Ke S. V., 29, is a mother of five children and resides with her husband in an outlying area. Three children are students and two are too young to attend school. To meet the daily expenses she has a business bringing the clothes from the factory and tailoring them at home. Her husband is a construction worker from village to village. She and her husband can earn collectively about $5 each day. This rainy season her house is flooding, so the travelling around is not so easy. Now Ke needs to have some more money to purchase more clothes in a large amount to increase her profit. The more clothes she has, the more income she makes.

loans.use: To purchase cloth to sew for a profit.

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Kem S. H., 27, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and two young children. She makes about $3 daily, selling groceries, while her husband makes $1.50 as a policeman. She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1200 to purchase more groceries to expand her current shop. She is also hoping to purchase a pig to raise and sell with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries; Purchase a pig

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn S., 61, has seven children and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Phaok Son. They work together selling groceries and they make around $2 each day. They have their parents to support as well in their household, so three of the children work in the garment factories. Horn S. is asking for a loan of $150 to purchase more groceries for their store. They believe that with the loan, the expansion of their business will bring about an increased income and a higher standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem C., 26, is married and lives with her husband and two young children in the Kampong Cham province. She works as a rice farmer and also sells the rice in the market, making about $2 each day. Her husband is a construction worker who makes around $3 each day. The weather conditions have not been favorable for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices, especially rice, to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chhem C. included. In light of the struggling economy, she is asking for a loan in the amount of $550 to purchase a cow to plow their farmland. She sees an opportunity to increase her income and believes that plowing the land will be a valuable investment.

loans.use: Purchase a cow to plow

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim K. E., 22, is a garment factory worker and earns $2 per day. Her husband Mr. Phal Phan, 26, has been a blacksmith since 2002, making around $3 each day. This couple has no children yet but they have an older mother to take care of. Now Phal wants to get a loan from Kiva to purchase more blacksmith tools.

loans.use: To purchase more blacksmith's tools to make her husband's work faster and easier.

loans.name: Mek

texts.en: Mek S., 50, is married with five children and lives in the Kampong Cham province. She works out of her home as a tailor, making around $2 each day. Her husband is a motortaxi driver who is able to generate $2 each day as well. Mek S. is asking for a loan of $1000 to raise chickens and pigs. She needs the money to purchase the animals and also the feed. Along with her ability to generate income through the purchase of animals, she would like to purchase a water pump. She believes that this loan can raise her standard of living and provide valuable resources for her family.

loans.use: Purchase chickens and pigs; Purchase water pump

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi S., 52 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) in 2003. She uses her loan from TYM Fund in breeding and retailing. She now has a variety store in the market. Her business is pretty good. She has 3 children, all of them got married. Two of out three moved out, so she and her husband now lives with the last one. Mrs. S. saw that there is a demand in construction. Thus, she discussed with her family to buy machines to make bricks. To implement this plan, her family wwill have to invest a great deal of money. That is why Mrs. S. would like to borrow 575USD to buy the machines. Mrs. S.'s family earns approximately 313USD per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Sâm 52 tuổi, năm 2003 chị tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, được vay vốn của Quỹ gia đình chị đã đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và buôn bán, hiện nay gia đình chị đang có 1 cửa hàng tạp hóa tại chợ việc buốn bán kinh doanh khá thuận lợi, Chị có 3 con và đã xây dựng gia đình, 2 con đã ra ở riêng, chị cùng chồng sống cùng với 1 người con, công việc kịnh doanh của gia đình chị đều do con chị làm, nhận thấy tại đia phương đang có nhu cầu về xây dựng, gia đình chị đã bàn bạc mua máy đùn gạch. Với kế hoạch này gia đình chị phải đầu tư một số vốn khá lớn. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ mua máy đùn gạch. Thu nhập bình quân: 5.000.000đ./ tháng.

loans.use: Agriculture

loans.name: Meth

texts.en: Meth S., 65, is a farmer living in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and three children. She typically makes $1 each day, and her husband makes about $2 working in construction. The climate conditions have been unfavorable in Cambodia this past year for farming, and this has caused food prices to soar. Inflation has also been out of control, as this has turned into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Meth S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase a pig to raise and eventually sell. She sees this business opportunity as a way to increase her income and to provide a higher standard of living for her and her family.

loans.use: Purchase a pig

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim H., 28, is a mother of one child and resides with her husband in an outskirt of town. Since 2006 she has worked at a garment factory not so far from her house. She makes about $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and also a fisherman. For sure, it still hard for the family even though her husband has two jobs, so right now Lim is requesting for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband, so he can run a business sometimes when he is free from his regular job.

loans.use: To purcahse a motor-bike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị T., 30 years old, took her husband’s advise to join the TYM Fund in 2003. Her first loan was modest at 500,000 VND. She used the funds to invest in raising pigs. The loan amounts increase gradually as she felt more comfortable with the weekly repayments. She got more pigs and expanded the facility. Besides raising pigs she weaves baskets for extra income. She takes in 3,000,000 VND a month. Her husband is a laborer with an average wage of 1,500,000 a month. They have a school aged child. She is applying for a loan of 9,000,000 VND to invest more into her raising pigs business.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Năm 2003 được sự động viên của chồng. Chị Nguyễn Thị T. 30 tuổi đã tham gia vào Quỹ, vòng vốn đầu tiên do chưa quen việc hoàn trả theo tuần nên gia đình chị vay mức vốn thấp 500.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, qua 1 vòng vốn vay gia đình chị đã quen dần với hình thức trả vốn theo tuần nên các vòng vốn tiếp theo gia đình chị vay các mức vốn cao hơn vẫn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, mô hình chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đã mở rộng và quy mô hơn, những lúc nhàn dỗi gia đình chị làm thêm nghề đan thúng để tăng thu nhập, chị có 1 con đang đi học, chồng chị là người chịu khó hàng ngày anh vẫn đi làm thuê thu nhập bình quân 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn nay gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Thu nhập bình quân. 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thi Toàn, 47 years old, joins the TYM Fund in 2003. She has 3 children. Two are still live with her. The oldest one has moved out. Her family is a traditional farmer family. She takes out loans to invest in raising poultry and pigs. The business earns her nice income of 3,000,000 VND a month that allows her to save enough to buy things for her house. Things like sewing machine, refrigerator. Her children also have jobs and bring in 3,000,000 VND a month. She is applying for a loan of 8,000,000 VND to invest more to her livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nguyễn Thi Toàn 47 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2003 chị sinh được 3 con hiên nay 2 con đang ở cùng chị, 1 con đã trưởng thành và ra ở riêng, gia đình chị làm nghề nông nghiệp khi tham gia Quỹ chị vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gà, lợn. Với kịnh nghiệm nhiều năm chăn nuôi nên công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị rất hiệu quả, từ kết quả chăn nuôi được kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển, gia đình chị đã tiết kiện để mua sắm được một số tiện nghi có giá trị như xe may, tủ lạnh…..Các con chị đã đi làm và có thu nhập phụ giúp gia đình bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 8.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Thu nhập bình quân. 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Ban H., 47, is a married with seven children and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh. Four of her children are married; two are employed by the garment factory; and the rest are students. Ban has business bringing the clothes from the factory and to sew at home. Normally she makes $1 per day. The majority of the income is from her husband, named Chan Lim. He is a motor-taxi driver and earns $6 each day.

Now Ban is requesting a loan to help her to create another business to earn more income in order to support her family. She wants to set up a small stand selling vegetables, beef and pork in front of her house.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her business and to set up a small stand selling vegetables, beef and pork in front of her house.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef, 41 years old and married with three children, has been a very reliable client of Al Majmoua for the past three years.  A hard worker, Youssef owns a floor polishing and gypsum decoration micro-enterprise in the city of Saida South, Lebanon. He now needs a loan of $1,200 to purchase a new floor polishing machine, a generator to allow him to continue working during the six to eight hours of daily power outages, and some gypsum material.

loans.use: To purchase a new floor polishing machine, a generator, and some gypsum material.

loans.name: Aslam Din

texts.en: Aslam Din is a young man and lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is very talented and has had a retail shop for more than five years. He is happy with his business, but would love to expand his business. When he found out about AFSG microfinance, he requested an individual loan to complete his stock and expand his business. This will enable him to make a better income and provide a better future for himself.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad, 50 years old, married with five children, lives in Saida South, Lebanon, where he owns a gas station and has been a client of Al Majmoua for two cycles already. He is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase motor oil tanks and a variety of car accessories he wants to sell at the station. With the tremendous increase in oil prices, Mohamad is thinking of ways to diversify the services offered by his gas station in order not to be completely dependent on the selling of gas and oil.

loans.use: To purchase motor oil tanks and a variety of car accessories.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan, 40 years old, married with three children, lives in Saida South, Lebanon, where he owns a microentreprise that sells electricA. accessories, assembles and repairs electric batteries, and sells and installs AC split units. He has been a client of A. Majmoua for the past three years. Hassan now needs a loan $1,200 to sustain the livelihood of his economically and socially vulnerable sister. Hassan is trying to help her open a small business that would provide an income sufficient to ensure her an acceptable living.

loans.use: To sustain the livelihood of his economically and socially vulnerable sister.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad, 32 years old, lives in Saida South, Lebanon, where he owns a small bakery shop specializing in selling "Manakish," the famous Lebanese "pizza" that everybody has for breakfast. Mohamad is requesting a loan of $1,200 to do an aluminum "vitrine" for his bakery.  He believes  this decorating work will improve the visibility of his shop.

loans.use: To do some decoration work in his bakery.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad, 26 years old, lives in Saida South, Lebanon, where he owns a hairdresser and barber shop. This is the second loan Ahmad is requesting from Al Majmoua. The first one, in the amount of $500, allowed him to do some decorating in his shop. This time, he needs another loan of $500 to complete the purchase of a second hand car.

loans.use: To complete the purchase of a second hand car.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad, 36 years old, lives in Saida, a city south of Beirut. Ahmad sells fruits and vegetables in the city streets and works from home repairing old furniture. Since he is now well-known in the area for furniture repair and has a good base of clients, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to open a furniture repair shop.  Ahmad believes that opening the shop will increase his income. This will be his second loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To open a furniture repair shop.

loans.name: Salman Ali

texts.en: Salman Ali lives in district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan, is married, and has a shoe store. He started his business five years ago, so he is experienced and has lots of clients. He would like to expand his business and needs a loan to import more shoes to sell in his store.  He would like to provide a better income for his family.

loans.use: To import more shoes.

loans.name: Ni Luh Roteh

texts.id:
Ni Luh Roteh used her first loan to buy pig food because previously she already owned a female pig and a piglet. Ni Luh Roteh already obtained some profit from the pig farming business. Despite the humble barn made of bamboo, Ni Luh Roteh is still very keen to develop the business. Using the second loan from Dinari, Ni Luh Roteh bought one female pig which cost Rp. 800,000. Since she started breeding it, it has produced 12 piglets. In three months, she could sell 12 pigs for Rp. 3,000,000. Her profit is Rp.2,000,000 after deducting the revenue with the pig food expense for 6 months. She hopes she can add one more female pig in the future so that she can gain more revenue.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Pada pinjaman pertama Ni Luh Roteh mempergunakan untuk membeli pakan karena sebelumnya ia sudah memiliki 1 ekor induk dan 1 ekor penggemukan. Ni Luh Roteh telah mendapat keuntungan dari usahanya beternaknya.Dengan kondisi kandang yang sederhana memakai kandang bambu Ni Luh Roteh tetap bersemangat dan ingin meningkatkan usaha peternakannya. Dengan mendapat tambahan modal pinjaman periode ke dua dari Dinari Ni Luh Roteh membeli 1 induk seharga Rp.800.000,- untuk dipelihara. Pada masa pemeliharaan sampai dengan saat ini sudah beranak sebanyak 12 ekor.dan bibit babinya dijual setelah dipelihara selama tiga bulan dengan harga Rp.3.000.000,-untuk 12 ekor. Dengan keuntungan sebesar Rp.2.000.000,- setelah dikurangi untuk biaya pakan selama enam bulan. Harapan kedepannya dia ingin menambah 1 induk lagi agar penghasilannya bisa bertambah.

loans.use: To buy female pig

loans.name: Ni Komang Suarniti

texts.id:
In the first phase of the loan Ni Komang Suarniti used it to buy 4 piglets for fattening, and also additional food. From this pig farming, Ni Komang Suarniti could help her husband in paying for daily expenses, and even from the profit Ni Komang Suarniti also repaired her pig stalls that initially was from bamboo wall to a batako wall. From this second phase of the loan Ni Komang Suarniti used it to buy 5 piglets for fattening for Rp 1,250,000 (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp8,000-9,500.00). During the time her pigs got sick, and although it was medically treatedm they died. Ni Komang Suarniti did not give up, and together with her husband, she wants to again buy piglets for fattening, and continue her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan modal pinjaman tahap pertama Ni Komang Suarniti menggunakan untuk membeli bibit babi penggemukan sebanyak 4 ekor dan juga mempergunakan untuk membeli pakan tambahan. Dengan usaha beternak tersebut Ni Komang Suarniti bisa membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup sehari- hari bahkan dari keuntungannya Ni Komang Suarniti juga memperbaiki kandang babinya yang semula dari dinding bambu dengan dinding batako. Pada pinjaman tahap kedua ini Ni Komang Suarniti menggunakan untuk membeli bibit babi penggemukan 5 ekor dengan total harga Rp. 1.250.000,-. Pada masa pemeliharaan babinya terkena penyakit dan walaupun sudah ditangani secara medis, namun babinya mati. Ni Komang Suarniti tidak patah semangat bersama suaminya dia mau membeli lagi bibit babi penggemukan untuk melanjutkan usahanya.

loans.use: To buy piglets (Membeli anak babi)

loans.name: Sayaad Naim

texts.en: S. Naim lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated and owns an internet cafe that has many customers. He wants to make his business more popular by enlarging his shop. Therefore, he needs a loan to buy one or two new computers to make the necessary improvements to his cafe. He is pleased that he will be able to make his business more successful.

loans.use: To buy one or two new computers

loans.name: Jero Ketut Meliani

texts.id:
From expanding her pig farming business after obtaining first phase loan from Dinari, Jero Ketut Meliani already felt the profit obtained. From that profit, Jero Ketut Meliani could help her husband to fulfill family needs, however she felt that she needed to increase her income. From the second phase loan from Dinari, Jero Ketut Meliani would use to buy 5 piglets for fattening. Within a period of 6 months, Jero Ketut Meliani could profit Rp 1,500,000. From this second phase loan, Jero Ketut Meliani expects to have larger profit to increase & better family's living standard.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan mengembangkan usaha beternak babi ketika mendapat pinjaman tahap pertama dari Dinari, Jero Ketut Meliani sudah merasakan keuntungan yang dia peroleh. Dari keuntungan tersebut Jero Ketut Meliani bisa membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya, namun dia merasa perlu untuk menambah penghasilannya. Dengan mendapatkan pinjaman tahap kedua dari Dinari Jero Ketut Meliani mempergunakan untuk membeli bibit babi 5 ekor dengan total harga Rp. 1.250.000,- untuk dipelihara secara penggemukan. Dalam 1 eriode selama 6 bulan Jero Ketut Melianibisa memperoleh keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.500.000,-. Melalui pinjaman tahap kedua ini Jero Ketut Meliani berharap dia bisa mendapat keuntungan yang lebih besar lagi untuk meningkatkan taraf hidup keluarganya menjadi lebih baik.

loans.use: To buy piglets and repair stall (Membeli anak babi dan memperbaiki kandang)

loans.name: San

texts.en: San P., 44, is a widow living in the Kampong Cham province with her four children. She is supported by her children who are in the garment factories and logging industry. San P. is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a small tractor. She will rent out her tractor to other farmers, and in so doing, generate a profit. She sees her area as having a need for a tractor to work the fields, and believes this opportunity will be able to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase a small tractor

loans.name: Desak Wiratni

texts.id:
Desak Wiartni recently follows her child's footstep to obtain a loan from Dinari foundation. In her first loan, Desak Wiartni obtained a loan for Rp 2,000,000 (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp8,000-9,500.00) that she used to expand her pig farming business. Since she only owned a mother pig, Desak Wiartni bought 4 more piglets for a Total price of Rp 1,000,000 for fattening. During a 6 month period, usually she could harvest 2 times. Feed expenses for 3 months are Rp 300,000. Profit are about Rp 1,0000,000 for 3 months. She hopes for the future that her pig farming business could expand larger, and could increase profit so that her family's living standard could increase.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Desak Wiartni baru mengikuti jejak anaknya yang sudah bergabung mendapat pinjaman dari Yayasan Dinari. Untuk Pinjaman pertama ini Desak Wiratni memperoleh pinjaman sebesar Rp. 2.000.000,- yang dipergunakan untuk mengembangkan usaha ternak babinya.Berhubung sudah mempunyai satu induk Desak Wiratni membeli lagi 4 ekor bibit babi dengan total harga Rp.1.000.000,- untuk dipelihara secara penggemukan. Dalam 1 periode selama 6 bulan biasanya dapat memanen sebanyak dua kali. Biaya pengeluaran selama tiga bulan untuk membeli pakan sebesar Rp.300.000,-.Keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.000.000,- dapat diperoleh selama tiga bulan.Harapan untuk kedepannya dari usaha ternak babinya dapat berkembang lebih besar lagi dan mendapat keuntungan lebih meningkat sehingga taraf hidup keluarganya menjadi lebih baik.

loans.use: To buy 4 piglets (Membeli 4 ekor anak babi)

loans.name: Huy

texts.en: Huy E., 48, is married and lives with her four children in the Kampong Cham province. Her husband is a farmer who makes around $1.60 each day, and three of her children work as well. Two of her children are farmers and one is a taxi driver. The agriculture industry has really suffered in Cambodia over the past year, as the climate has had unfavorable conditions and inflation has been high. Huy E. is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a small truck for her son to run his business. With this purchase, the family believes that it can increase its income and raise the standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase a small truck

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ving

texts.en: Ving C., 52, lives with her two children and a niece in the Kampong Cham province. She typically makes $3.30 a day selling silk skirts and cotton scarves in her area. She is also supported by her two children, who work in the garment factories. Ving C. is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase more silk skirts and scarves. She believes that increasing her inventory and selling the clothes in larger amounts will increase her income and raise her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase more silk skirts and scarves

loans.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam N., 39, has been working very hard with her husband to support the family. This couple has four children and all of them are students. Saom has a business preparing a pieces of clothing to take them to the factory to earn a commission. She makes $1.50 per day. Her husband, 39, has been a plumber since 2001, making $4 per day.
Soam is now requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a sewing maching to provide a tailoring service to the people in her community, which is better than working as a contract seamstress.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and cloth to run a business

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S., 42, is married and lives with her four children in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making around $2 each day, while her husband works as a rice miller. Her husband makes about $4 each day, however, they must also support an older sister and mother at home. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. Chea S. is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase more rice. They will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Meav

texts.en: Meav R., 58, is married and works together with her husband and two of her children in the Kampong Cham province.
